title: Gunnar Garfors breaks records visiting 22 American states in less than 24 hours
text:
1
View
comments
For many planning to visit another state or country, it requires research and time; but a plucky explorer and his two friends smashed world records to become the first to visit a whopping 22 US states in just 24 hours.
Norwegian adventurer, Gunnar Garfors, who previously managed to visit all 198 countries around the globe while maintaining a full-time job, started the incredible 24 hour challenge in Maine on September 20.
Garfors, along with fellow travellers Tay-young Pak and Øystein Djupvik crossed the border of Illinois having hired three rental cars and three scheduled flights for their journey.
Scroll down for video
State number one: The team started at 6.20am on September 20 in Maine, for their 24-hour challenge
The intrepid mission took them through 22 states from Maine to Illinois during a single day and night
Adventurer Gunnar Garfors (centre), along with Tay-young Pak (left) and Øystein Djupvik (right) pictured in New Hampshire. A member of the public had bet $80 that the trio would only manage to visit two states in 24 hours
'It was an exhilarating feeling, a total adrenalin kick!' Garfors told MailOnline Travel.
'We were tired, but weary – yet incredibly happy! It took quite a lot of planning, and so many things could have gone wrong.'
The intrepid trio not only beat the previous record of 19 states in one day and night, but also beat their own target.
'We had aimed for 20 states, so 22 was well within margin,' Garfors said.

Most of the wheel-time was undertaken by Djupvik, but it was actually flights which caused the most problems for the speedy group.
'We could have managed 23 had there been no flight delays, though,' he commented.
Their route took them from Maine to New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Vermont, New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, Alabama, North Carolina, Mississippi, Arkansas, Missouri, Kentucky – and finally ending in Illinois.

Their third state of Massachussetts ruined the bet for the man. The friends said they had fun trying to pronounce the lake name on the sign pictured
The fourth stop was Connecticut where the group narrowly avoided being spat at by the llamas in the background
They next travelled to Rhode Island where they vowed to spend longer next time they visit
It took a few months to plan the record-breaking attempt with the team focusing on clusters of states that could be easily connected with scheduled planes.
'We were in three states for literally a minute: Rhode Island, West Virginia and Kentucky,' Garfords said.
'The others were visited for longer. We were longest in Massachusetts (a lot of road to cover), New York (delayed plane), Virginia (delayed flight) and Mississippi (a lot of road to cover).'
Despite the long travel time, the trio decided to journey in style, with chef Tay-young Pak serving fresh lobster and oysters from the back seat.
Taking advantage of Maine's delicious seafood, the adventurers managed to buy 15 giant lobsters for less than the equivalent of £4 a piece.
On a mission: A quick stop off in Vermont allowed the group time to go quickly to a church
State number seven was New York where the trio encountered lumberjacks and quaint shops by the side of the road
The team next visited Pennsylvania in order to pick up a new car to continue with their speedy journey
In order to fund the record breaking trip, Norwegian betting company ComeOn set up bets on how many states the team could manage, and what would be their final destination.
Members of the public were able to bet on these numbers, which helped to motivate the group.
'One guy put $80 on us managing only two states. He lost his cash rather early!' Garfors said.
The idea of the American trip came to the team following their success breaking the world record one year ago to visit 19 countries in 24 hours.
'I suggested to do something in the US – and we soon came up with the concept of visiting the most states in 24 hours – jokingly calling it the world’s fastest book promotional trip. I left a book in most states we went through – finder’s keepers.' the Norwegian traveller said.
Sunshine state of mind: The weather was ideal and contrasting in the trio's ninth state of New Jersey
State number 10 was Delaware pictured. The travellers kept their energy levels up by cooking in the back of their vehicles while on the road
Next time? The team were sad that they didn't have time for crab cakes when they reached their 11th state, Maryland
The trio say they are now aiming to break one travel related world record a year.
They haven’t decided on next year’s mission, but are open to most ideas, particular if they are slightly manic and crazy.
'Most adults have forgotten how to play, they are being serious to the extreme all the time,' Garfors said.
'We aim to avoid going into that adult trap. Playing is underestimated and a great way to maintain a friendship too.
What is also really heart-warming is that we get a lot of messages from people who say they are inspired by us when we engage in such trips, that following our dreams make them smile and see possibilities and that they find It refreshingly different that we not only talk about doing strange and borderline idiotic trips, but actually do them too – sometimes by stretching the limits.'

Learning a lesson: In Virginia, their 12th state, the travellers even had a bit of time to check out a local school. They also left a book in every state that they visited
Next they managed to visit West Virginia, although they wished they could go whitewater rafting instead of just passing through
State number 14 was North Carolina. Tadjik the taxi driver promised he could drive to South Carolina and back in a maximum of 35 minutes. And he did!
As night time descended the team were in South Carolina, but couldn't see much of the landscape in the dark
In Alabama, two out of their three American Airlines flights were delayed, but the trio had managed to visit 16 states at this point
Nearing the finish line: The friends took a selfie in Mississippi but were sad that there were no river boats to be seen
Clocks ticking: In their 18th state of Tennessee, the trio had time to stop for a jam in Memphis
In Arkansas they equalled the current record, 19 states in 24 hours, although no Clintons showed up to celebrate
The jubilant team celebrated having beaten the record, as they crossed the border of Missouri...but why stop there?
State number 21 was Kentucky, which the team said deserved more than a U-turn, but would have to wait until they weren't on a time deadline to see more of the state
Finish line! The triumphant team managed to reach Illinois after a manic 24 hours of travelling and were ecstatic to beat the record. They now plan to break one travel world record every year
